user.biography: Home of the tallest peak in North America, Denali was the first national park established to conserve wildlife in 1917.

node.accessibility_caption: the underside of a yellow-gilled mushroom

node.text:
Alaskans are known for harvesting food from nature’s abundant reserves, and each year, an amazing number of mushrooms make an appearance within the boundaries of Denali National Park. Seeming to appear overnight, these fungi can be found on the ground in the coniferous and deciduous forests, growing on trees or in bogs, and in open fields. 

For edibility, mushrooms are ranked from choice to deadly poisonous, with harvesting possible from spring through fall, depending on species. If you plan to eat any fungi, be sure you are familiar with that species from past experience or talk to an expert. Always cook mushrooms before eating and be advised that some edible mushrooms are poisonous if not thoroughly cooked! 

NPS Photos: K. Miller / R. Hann

node.accessibility_caption: the underside of a yellow-gilled mushroom
The cap of a cream-colored mushroom with peeling dark brown coat
Whitish stalked fungi ending in nubs similiar to coral
A slender stemmed brown mushroom with a delicate cap
brownish shelf fungus with wavy yellow edges growing on a tree trunk
Gray skies. A river bar between two mountains, dusted in snow. Red and orange shrubs in the foreground.

node.text:
What does August look like where you live?

🏔The most recent storm system Denali experienced left the higher elevation mountain tops dusted with snow. In Alaska, this early snow is known colloquially as “termination dust” and is the first sign of the approaching winter. 

❄Much of this early snow will melt off before winter sets in, but it's not uncommon to see snow showers on and off through August and September.

🚙Planning on visiting in the upcoming weeks? Check our current weather conditions on the Denali National Park current conditions page. Link in bio.

Image: NPS Photo/Leah Mellencamp

node.accessibility_caption: A wet grizzly bear stands in a grassy field in the rain.

node.text:
"If you like piña coladas and getting caught in the rain..."-Rupert Holmes

But do you like getting caught in the rain? While our grizzly bears are happy to forage and hunt in the mist, humans need to take a few extra steps for maximum comfort.

August is one of the rainiest months in Denali. If you're planning on visiting the park in the upcoming weeks, make sure to:
• Pack layers. Rain jackets, gloves, base layers, and hats are great ideas for clothing to pack, especially if you are planning on hitting the trails.
• Check the weather. Conditions can change rapidly in Denali, so make sure to check for possible storms, warnings, or updates. With the varying elevations within the park, it's not uncommon to see rain and snow happening across the same storm system.
• Visit the Current Conditions page. Curious about possible Ranger-led walks? Road conditions? Need information about campgrounds or buses? Visit www.nps.gov/dena for more information on the latest happenings.

How does the weather compare where you live?

Image: NPS Photo/Emily Mesner

node.accessibility_caption: Small white flower growing from a rocky surface in the foreground with snowy, rocky mountains in the background.

node.text:
Have you ever found a neat looking rock? In Denali, we have rocks from all kinds of origins: from oceans to volcanoes, from deep underground to glaciers on the surface, and even huge underground caverns of lava! By looking at the colors, textures, and locations of a rock, we can see the journey that it took to get to that place.  All of these different rock journeys come together to make habitable soil, even in incredibly unhospitable places. 

In Denali, geology, the study of the rocks, means studying ancient volcanoes and oceans, current glacier movement, frequent earthquakes, and especially landslides. The study of these rocks can help us understand the life that survives on top of them. 

Next time you are outside, find a rock and see if you can imagine the incredible journey it took just to find you! 

© Anastasia Brease

node.accessibility_caption: Blue sky and fluffy clouds float by as a young person sits on a rocky outcropping and writes in a journal.

node.text:
It's Monday!
Your to-do list is long, but what about your "to-don't" list?
Tell us how you plan to spend 5 minutes in contemplation or experiencing joy today! 🌲
Nobody ever died thinking "I wish I'd spent more time on Social Media" but you may wish you didn't miss out on moments of bliss or quiet!

NPS Photo

node.accessibility_caption: A tan, white, and black dog lays on the ground with his paws crossed regally in front of him, eyes half closed

node.text:
No snow? No problem. Though winter is every sled dog’s favorite season, the canine rangers do enjoy Denali’s short summer as well.  Do you share any of the dogs’ summertime hobbies? 
-	Sunbathing 🌞
-	Digging in the dirt 🐾
-	Smelling flowers 🌷
-	Chasing after balls ⚽️
-	Making new friends 😁

#SleddogSunday 
NPS Photos

node.accessibility_caption: A tan, white, and black dog lays on the ground with his paws crossed regally in front of him, eyes half closed
A dog's head disappears into a hole in the ground as his rump sticks out and loose dirt is spread about
A fluffy dog head sniffs some small pale flowers
A black and white dog and a tan dog in actions chasing an unseen object
A black and white dog gets belly rubs from two smiling people
Photo by Denali National Park on August 13, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
“And I knew exactly what to do. But in a much more real sense, I had no idea what to do.” 
-Michael Scott, The Office

Bears are one the most amazing animals to see here in Denali National Park & Preserve! There are many ways to see them safely as well. However, while out hiking visitors may encounter a bear. Though bears look cute and cuddly, they can be very dangerous.
To help prevent an encounter of a bear:

•	Stay at minimum 300 yards or 3 football fields away from any bear.
•	Make lots of noise while hiking. Sing or talk in a loud and carrying voice so that any bear in the area knows that humans are around. 
•	Do not rely on bear bells. Bears tend to ignore them, or they do not alert the bear to your presence until you are much too close.
•	When camping at a campground, never leave food or smelly things like sunscreen or toothpaste in or near your tent. Always cook in a cook shelter if there is one!
•	Never leave a bag of food or smelly things unattended at any time, even in populated places like visitor centers, bus stops, or parking lots. This even includes car seats! Not just bears want to know what’s inside!

Image: Bear standing on hind legs seeming staring at the camera. The bear is on a slope with some brush and assorted wild flowers. 

NPS Photo: Kent Miller

node.accessibility_caption: Sled dogs running along a snow-covered trail pulling a musher and sled.

node.text:
Want to learn about the sled dogs of Denali but can’t visit in person? Watch a recorded version of “The Science of Sled Dogs,” a Distance Learning program. Find out why park rangers use sled dogs to perform winter work and how these amazing animals are perfectly adapted to a cold, subarctic environment. Watch it here: www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=95C7DCB7-0017-4519-AD2B-7B2CA3316B35

Any time of year, whether you’re a student, parent, or teacher, you can access the wonders of Denali National Park through virtual learning opportunities. Check out our website for more information: www.nps.gov/dena/learn/education/education-resources.htm

#InternationalYouthDay 
NPS Photo / Tim Rains

node.accessibility_caption: A caribou runs through red shrubbery with a medal around its neck

node.text:
Feeling fired up after watching the Olympics? Meet the medalists in the Denali Wildlife Olympics and challenge yourself to try out their events!

🏅The Caribou Sprint: Measure out 100 feet. Start the stopwatch and go! Did you beat the caribou? They can cover 100 feet in 1.3 seconds, sprinting up to 50 mph to escape predators.

🏅The Snowshoe Hare Long Leap: Mark a spot on the floor and stand on the starting line. Hop as far as you can. A snowshoe hare can jump ten times their body length- 10 feet in one hop! 

🏅The Sandhill Crane Balancing Event: Start a timer and stand on one leg for as long as possible. Sandhill cranes will balance on one leg for up to an hour while their other foot is tucked into their feathers to keep it warm. 

How did you stack up against Denali’s wild athletes? Did you have a favorite event? 

NPS Photos

node.accessibility_caption: A caribou runs through red shrubbery with a medal around its neck
A snowshoe hare, mostly brown with white feet, sits with medal around its neck
A sandhill crane stands on one leg with a medal around its neck, green vegetation and logs in background
Photo by Denali National Park on August 10, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
The surging Muldrow Glacier has changed a part of the landscape for people and wildlife.  The last surge was 65 years and changed this portion of landscape from a crossable (for people and animals) moonscape of rocky gravel over stagnant ice, to a massive spikey unstable mass of un-crossable ice for people and even baffling to the Dall Sheep!  Imagine that generations of Dall Sheep would have crossed this area to access hills and mountain sides of prime grazing habitat but are now blocked by a suddenly very different landscape.

Have you ever had to change your travel plans due to an unexpected event?

For more information on the surging Muldrow Glacier, please follow this link.  https://www.nps.gov/articles/dena-muldrow.htm

Photo credit: Gentry Sewell

Images: Dall Sheep near the Muldrow Glacier

Canada Lynx sits in patch of grass. It is gray and brown with tufted ears.

node.text:
Happy #InternationalCatDay!

Canada Lynx (lynx canadenis) is Denali’s only feline resident. This elusive creature is known for its snowshoe like paws and fluffy black ear tufts. In the winter months, they have a thick coat and utilize their large paws to easily traverse across snowy plains. Like most stealthy predators, Lynx have extremely well adapted hearing and eyesight; they can often spot small prey from up to 250 ft away!

Fun Fact: The Lynx is a crepuscular species, meaning they are most active during dawn and dusk, making it an extra special wildlife spotting during the day time!

Images 1 and 2: NPS Photo/Ken Conger

node.accessibility_caption: Canada Lynx sits in patch of grass. It is gray and brown with tufted ears.
Canada Lynx sits in patch of grass. It is gray and brown with tufted ears.

node.text:
Meet Denali’s alpine wildlife! Dall sheep (Ovis dalli) are found in the high mountains of Northwestern North America, and are related to bighorn sheep. They are one of the “big five” mammals to look for in Denali; watch for them resting and feeding on ridges and steep slopes or out on the rocks and crags trying to avoid predators!

Fun Fact: Male Dall sheep are called “rams” and have large, curling, horns. Female Dall sheep are called “ewes” and have shorter, spiky, horns. The male’s horns will begin to curve around age 3, so young rams can be difficult to tell apart from ewes. 

The Denali Alpine Wildlife project (@denalialpinewildlife), with Denali National Park and Preserve (@denalinps) and the University of Montana (@umwildlife), seeks to understand how Alaska’s changing temperatures, weather patterns, and landcover are impacting where alpine wildlife can live now, and where they might be able to live in the future. 

Are you planning to visit Denali National Park, AK? Become a citizen scientist!  You can join the project by taking photographs of alpine wildlife, particularly collared pika, hoary marmots, arctic ground squirrels, and Dall sheep, while you are out hiking in the park and uploading them to iNaturalist (see the last slide for instructions) or emailing them to us at denalialpinewildlife@gmail.com.

NPS Photo / Jen Wall

Alt Text: A male Dall sheep with large, curving horns and white-colored fur is climbing a rocky mountain-side with its rear end facing toward the camera but its head turned back toward the camera as well. 

#denalialpinewildlife #denalinps #denalinationalpark #umwildlife #umontana #citizenscience
